news.title: Ericsson's shares soar after profit beat, shrugs off tariffs
news.summary: STORY: Ericsson shares soared more than 14% in early morning trade Tuesday.Investors bought in after the firm reported a better-than-expected rise in quarterly earnings.Income before tax and interest hit $1.62 billion - almost a tenth higher than analyst forecasts.The number also excluded restructuring charges at the Swedish telecoms equipment maker Cost savings and a dominant position in North America have helped Ericsson stay ahead of Nordic rival Nokia in the 5G race.The group has also outperformed rivals in winning U.S. contracts, mainly a $14 billion deal with AT&T.Ericsson also played down the impact of U.S. tariffs.While the firm warned no company is immune to the duties, they currently don't see more impact from it going forward.Third-quarter net sales were 9% down from a year ago at just under $5.9 billion, but came in above the analysts' expectations.However, sales in the Americas slowed down by 8% from last year.Ericsson completed the sale of its Iconectiv business in August, which led to a one-off profit gain of almost $800 million.Ericsson also announced a five-year partnership with Vodafone Tuesday.The plan is to modernize the operator's programmable networks.Financial details of the deal weren't disclosed.

news.title: J&J faces first UK lawsuits alleging its baby powder caused cancer
news.summary: STORY: Johnson & Johnson is facing its first lawsuits in the United Kingdom over alleged cancer-causing talc products.That comes as the drugmaker fights tens of thousands of similar claims in the United States.Legal firm KP Law said it filed a lawsuit Tuesday at the English High Court on behalf of 3,000 people who say their ovarian cancer or other diseases were caused by using J&J's baby powder between 1965 and 2023.The firm says J&J's talc products contained carcinogenic fibers, including asbestos which is often linked to mesothelioma, a deadly form of cancer.The value of the lawsuit against J&J and a subsidiary of its former consumer health unit Kenvue, is estimated at just over $1.3 billion.Kenvue said in a statement that J&J baby powder "did not contain asbestos, and does not cause cancer".J&J stopped selling talc-based baby powder in the U.S. in 2020, switching to a cornstarch product.It did the same in the UK in 2023.The company has sought to resolve the tens of thousands of similar lawsuits in the U.S. through bankruptcy.But federal courts rejected the strategy three times.

news.title: Thousands sue Johnson & Johnson in UK over cancer claims
news.summary: Johnson & Johnson (J&J) is facing legal action from thousands of people in the UK who are accusing the global healthcare giant of knowingly selling talcum powder contaminated with asbestos.  More than 3,000 people allege they or a family member developed forms of ovarian cancer or mesothelioma from using Johnson's baby powder between 1965 and 2023.  A lawsuit has been filed by KP Law at the High Court in London seeking damages against J&J and Kenvue UK, which was split from the former in 2023 and now operates as a separate business.

news.title: TSMC profits blow past market forecast thanks to AI boom
news.summary: STORY: :: TSMCChip giant TSMC posted a record-breaking third-quarter profit Thursday, up 39.1%, smashing market expectations.But looming U.S. tariffs could cloud its outlook.Riding the AI boom, the company reported a net profit of nearly $15 billion, marking its sixth straight quarter of double-digit growth.:: FileDemand from major players like Apple and Nvidia continues to boost its bottom line.The Taiwan firm says AI demand is still strengthening, and is higher now than it had expected only three months ago. That follows similarly robust outlooks from other major tech players, including South Korea's Samsung and European chip gear leader ASML - a big supplier to TSMC. Despite the strong results, uncertainty looms.U.S. tariffs imposed by Donald Trump's administration weigh on the outlook.:: TSMCStill, TSMC is pushing ahead with a $100 billion U.S. expansion.That's on top of $65 billion already pledged for three plants in Arizona, one already operational.:: File TSMC shares are up 38% this year, outpacing Taiwan’s broader market as investors so far shrug off the tariff risks.
